entry.title: If it walks like a duck...
entry.content:
Consider two finite algebras that are the same except for a relabelling of the operations. Our intuition tells us that these are simply different names for the same mathematical structure. According to the standard definitions, however, not only are such algebras distinct mathematical objects, but also they are not even isomorphic!

Isotopy is another well known notion of “sameness” that is broader than isomorphism. However, in a recent paper I proved that isotopy is not a notion of algebraic equivalence.

$\def\bA{\bf A} \def\bB{\bf B}$ Here is an example of two algebraic structures that are obviously the same except for a relabelling of the operations: let $\bA$ be an algebra of size 4 and label the elements of the universe ${1,2,3,4}$. Suppose $\bA$ has two unary operations, which we label $f^\bA$ and $g^\bA$, and suppose $f^\bA$ is the permutation $(1,2)(3,4)$ and $g^\bA$ is the permutation $(1,3)(2,4)$.

Now let $\mathbf{B}$ be defined in almost the same way except we let $f^\bB$ be the permutation $(1,3)(2,4)$ and let $g^\bA$ be the permutation $(1,2)(3,4)$.

Clearly we have simply swapped the names of the operations, and any sane person would agree that we have two “equivalent” algebraic structures. But these are not considered equivalent, and they are not even isomorphic according to the classical definition.

(Insert brief paragraph about isotopy here.)

The Isotopy GitHub repository contains an article in which I present algebras that are isotopic and yet have vastly different congruence lattices.

Congruence relations of algebras are the kernels of homomorphisms, and the congruence lattice is a basic “algebraic” feature of an algebra. Certainly we cannot accept a notion of “sameness” that equates two algebras with different congruence lattices.

entry.title: IEProps
entry.content:
The IEPost GitHub repository contains a draft of the article Interval enforceable properties of finite groups, to appear in Communications in Algebra.

The paper has been accepted and is in the final review stage. It should appear in print sometime in 2014. The original submission is available in the file DeMeo-IEProps-rev1.pdf. The latest revision is in the tex directory.

For questions, comments, or suggestions please submit an issue.

Thanks for your interest in this work!
